children.description: *number of seeds planted per hectare (ha) to ensure normal density of sprouts and a maximum yield. The seeding rate is expressed by the number of germinating seeds (millions) and the weight of the seeds (kg) [The Great Soviet Encyclopedia (1979)]
children.name: Changes in planting density/seeding rate*
Changes in planting depth, including planting in ridges/heaps
Changes in breeding/seeding/planting method (e.g., direct seeding vs. transplanting, seed priming)
Changes in re-planting/re-sowing (e.g., after a climate hazard, or to spread the risk)

children.description:
*In agriculture, multiple cropping is the practice of growing two or more crops in the same piece of land in same growing seasons instead of one crop. It is a form of polyculture (i.e., double-cropping, intercropping, e.g., relay cropping).
**Mixed cropping/polyculture/intercropping/co-cultivation: form of agriculture in which more than one species is grown at the same time and place
***Intercropping (mixed cropping in a defined pattern): multiple cropping practice involving growing two or more crops in proximity (i.e., mixed (inter)cropping (e.g., companion planting), row cropping, temporal intercropping (growing fast and slow growing plants simoultanesly), relay cropping (second crop is sown during the growht of first crop, so that the first one is harvested to make room for the full development of the second))
****Sequential cropping: growing crops in sequence within a crop year, one crop being sown after the harvest of the other
children.name: Changes in multiple cropping* (e.g., mixed cropping**/intercropping***, sequential cropping****)
Changes in crop rotation* (for changes in fallowing see 'Changes in fallowing')
Changes in soil conservation [not further specified]
Changes in using technical soil covers (e.g., plastic)
Changes in the use of fallowing practices

children.description: * Transhumance: type of pastoralism or nomadism, a seasonal movement of livestock between fixed summer and winter pastures (generally only the herds travel, with a certain number of people necessary to tend them, while the main population stays at the base).

children.description: * Financial capital, e.g., cash, savings, credit and debt (formal, informal), remittances, pensions, wages, and other economic assets.
children.name: Changes in financial capitals* from incomes [not further specified]
Changes in loans, credits and insurance
Changes in savings and financial backup (e.g., through one-off sellings)
Changes in receiving remittance or other financial support
Changes in income through market interactions/selling livelihood-related products (e.g., food vs. cash crops)
Changes in income from selling prepared food, hand(i)craft/artisan/artwork, traditional medicine
Changes in income from other work (in a non-/low natural dependent sector/business)

children.description: * Physical capital, e.g., infrastructure (affordable transport systems, roads, vehicles, secure shelter and buildings, water supply and sanitation, energy, good communications, access to information), household goods and utensils (e.g., refrigerators, radio), productive capital that enhance income, such as tools and technology (tools and equipment for production, e.g., rickshaws, sewing machines, seed, fertilizer, pesticides, traditional technology, other agricultural equipment).
children.name: Changes in the housing material and structure (including isolation)
Changes in the water infrastructure for household use, including storage facilities (e.g., pipes, tanks)
Changes in the construction and quality of storage facilities related to household use (e.g., for food), excluding water storage facilities
Changes in the construction of natural barrier construction against hazards/risks for housings (e.g., inundations, storms, salt instrusions, fire, �)
Changes in the construction of technical barrier construction against hazards/risks for housings (e.g., inundations, storms, salt instrusions, fire, �)
Changes in other physical capitals and  technologies (items/tools, materials) related to household use

children.description: * Natural capital, i.e., natural resource stocks (soil, water, air, genetic resources etc.) and environmental services (hydrological cycle, pollution sinks etc.), e.g., land and produce, water and aquatic resources, trees and forest products, wildlife, wild foods and fibers, biodiversity, environmental services.
children.name: Changes in land & water access due to ownership changements (e.g., productive land, forest, �.)
Changes in access to common land and water or to natural resources (e.g., access restriction due to environmental protection, limitation of catch/hunting quota)
Changes in active renaturalisation/regeneration through afforestation or plantings (e.g., of native species)
Changes in other means to increase or protect natural capital (e.g., biodiversity)

children.description: * Human capital, e.g., skills, knowledge, education, good health, physical capability, nutrition, capacity to work/ability to labor, capacity to adapt.
children.name: Changes in education, knowledge, awareness raising and practical skills
Changes in gender roles in livelihood and household activities
Changes in the use of environmental observation (e.g., traditional weather forecast, relying on past experiences, monitoring)
Changes in the use of institutional/technical/external information and warning sytems (e.g., weather forecast/climate reports)

children.description: * Social capital, e.g., networks and connections (patronage, neighborhoods, kinship), relations of trust and mutual understanding and support, formal and informal groups, shared values and behaviors, common rules and sanctions, collective representation, mechanisms for participation in decision-making, leadership.
children.name: Changes in relationships with family members/relatives and neighbours (e.g., friendships, degree of trust, willingness for reciprocal help)
Collective/community-based sharing/pooling/gifting/non-monetary exchange of things, including livelihood products
Changes in participation in community-based/common/collective actions/support (e.g., meetings, memberships, collective work)
Changes in spirituality (e.g., traditional ceremonies/sacrificial offerings/praying)
Changes in receiving regular free external support/assistance/material supply and aid (e.g., food supply by NGO), excluding financial support
Changes in requesting/receiving external help/asistance/support in times of emergency

Changes in timing and duration of daily household activities
Changes in the distance to water sources for household use
Changes in temporal/seasonal close-by vertical relocation of residence (changes in elevation)
Changes in temporal/seasonal close-by horizontal relocation of residence (e.g., within the community/district)
Changes in temporal/seasonal faraway relocation of residence (e.g., outside the community/district; migration to urban area in search for work)
Changes in permanent/long-term close-by vertical relocation of residence (changes in elevation)
Changes in permanent/long-term close-by horizontal relocation of residence (e.g., within the community/district)

Changes in temporal/seasonal faraway relocation of other livelihood/work activities (e.g., outside the community/district; to urban area) without moving residence
Changes in permanent/long-term faraway relocation of other livelihood/work activities (e.g., outside the community/district; to urban area) without moving residence
Changes in the quantity of food consumption
Changes in the usage of traditional medicine
Changes in the usage of conventional medicine, including visits to hospitals and medical centers
Changes in disinfection/cleaning treatment of food, water and so forth (e.g., by boiling/cooking)
Other health protections, including well-being (e.g., hygiene, sun protection, use of mosquito nets)
Changes in quantity of water consumption/use in the household [not further specified]
Changes in water sources for household use [not further specified]
Changes in the quantity of household use of groundwater from wells/boreholes
Changes in the quantity of rainwater/runoff harvesting* for household use
Changes in the quantity of household use of freshwater from surface water (e.g., rivers/streams/lakes/ponds)
Changes in the quantity of reused/recycled wastewater for household use
Changes in the quantity of other household resource use (other than water and food)
Changes in buying food and water, including food crops
Changes in buying other products and resources related to livelihood (e.g., feed)
Changes in buying other means and resources (e.g., petroleum)
Changes in storing other food products for household use
Changes in storing water for household use
Changes in storing other materials and products related to household use
Changes in other protection of items/tools, materials and products related to household use
Changes in the use of safty equipment and protecting shelter
Changes in taking actions in times of emergency, other than evacuation (e.g., fighting fires, floodings)
Changes in evacuation of belongings & people
Changes in other behavior with (pre-) caution related to living

level_names: LACCI (Local Adaptation to Climate Change Impacts)
laccis.name: adaptation_tree

children.description: Refers to a general change in temperature, not associated with a specific season or time of the day (e.g., ´nowadays it is warmer than in the past´)
children.name: Changes in mean temperature (not further specified)
Changes in the frequency of hot / warm days
Changes in the frequency of cold days
Changes in the temperature during the night
Changes in the temperature during the day

children.description: Refers to changes in temperature associated with elevation. E.g., ´now it is warmer on higher altitudes´, or ´it is now much colder in the valleys´
children.name: Changes in temperature associated with elevation

children.description: Refers to changes in the variation of temperature during the same day or in days close to each other. E.g., ´before the mornings used to be cold and the afternoons warm, now the whole day is hot´.
children.name: Changes in temperature fluctuations

children.description: A ´heat wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much warmer than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of heat waves

children.description: A ´heat wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much warmer than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Changes in the length / duration of heat waves

children.description: A ´heat wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much warmer than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Changes in the intensity / strength of heat waves

children.description: A ´cold wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much colder than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of cold waves

children.description: A ´cold wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much colder than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Changes in the length / duration of cold waves

children.description: A ´cold wave´ is a period of consecutive days in which temperatures are much colder than the average temperatures for that period.
children.name: Change in the intensity / strength of cold waves
Changes in the frequency of days with extreme temperatures

children.description: Choose this option if the observation refers to unusual temperatures in a speficic season (e.g., ´now there are cold days during summer´, or ´now there are warm days during the rainy season´).
children.name: Changes in the frequency of unusual temperatures in a given season

children.description: Choose this option if the observation refers to a general change in temperature in a specific season (e.g., ´now summers are colder´, or ´now the rainy season is warmer´).
children.name: Changes in the mean temperature in a given season
Changes in the frequency of extreme cold seasons
Changes in the intensity / strength of extreme cold seasons
Changes in the frequency of extreme hot seasons
Changes in the intensity / strength of extreme hot seasons
Changes in the frequency of sunny days

children.description: Refers to a general change in precipitation, not associated with a specific season or time of the day. E.g., ´nowadays it rains more than in the past´
children.name: Changes in mean rainfall (not further specified)
Changes in the number of days with rainfall / rainy days (not further specified)

children.description: Refers to general changes in the intensity of rainfall. E.g., ´rains were heavier in the past´.
children.name: Changes in the intensity / strength of rainfall (not further specified)

children.description: Refers to changes in the intensity of rainfall specifically during heavy rainfall events.
children.name: Changes in the intensity / strength of heavy rainfall events
Changes in the frequency of heavy rainfall events

children.description: Flash floods are floods that occur a short time (3-6 hours) after a heavy precipitation event
children.name: Changes in the frequency of flash floods

children.description: Flash floods are floods that occur a short time (3-6 hours) after a heavy precipitation event
children.name: Changes in the intensity / strength of flash floods

children.description: Refers to general changes in the variability of rainfall. E.g., ´rain is now more variable´
children.name: Changes in variability of rainfall (not further specified)

children.description: Changes in rainfall distribution along the year or between years. E.g., ´rain used to occur throughout the year, now it is concentrated only in a few months´, ´before we had rain every year, now we have some years with a lot of rain and other years with almost no rain´
children.name: Changes in temporal distribution of rainfall

children.description: Changes in rainfall distribution in space. E.g., ´in the past it used to rain in the valleys and up the mountains, now it rains only in the mountains´
children.name: Changes in the spatial distribution of rainfall
Changes in the length / duration of rainfall events

children.description: Use this category when the local perception of change refers specifically to predictability. E.g., ´now it is harder to predict when it is going to rain´.
children.name: Changes in the predictability of rainfall

children.description: A dry spell is defined as a period of consecutive days in which the amount of rainfall is much lower than the average for that period.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of dry spells

children.description: A dry spell is defined as a period of consecutive days in which the amount of rainfall is much lower than the average for that period.
children.name: Changes in the length /duration of dry spells

children.description: A wet spell is defined as a period of consecutive days in which the amount of rainfall is much higher than the average for that period.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of wet spells

children.description: A wet spell is defined as a period of consecutive days in which the amount of rainfall is much higher than the average for that period.
children.name: Changes in the length /duration of wet spells

children.description: Choose this option if the observation refers to changes in the amount of rainfall in a speficic season (e.g., ´now there is less rain in autumn´ or ´the rainy season is now drier´).
children.name: Changes in the amount of rainfall in a given season

children.description: Choose this option if the observation refers to changes in the intensity rainfall in a speficic season (e.g., ´now the summer rains are stronger´, or ´now the rains during the rainy season are weaker´).
children.name: Changes in the intensity / strength of rainfall in a given season

children.description: Choose this option if the observation refers to changes in the variation of rainfall in a speficic season (e.g., ´now the summer rains are more erratic´, or ´now the rains during the rainy season are less constant than they used bo be´).
children.name: Changes in the variation of rainfall in a given season

children.description: A drought is an event of prolongued shortages in water supply, usually from precipitation but may also refer to shortages in ground or surface water. It is usually identified through the observation of multiple biophysical indicators.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of drought events

children.description: A drought is an event of prolongued shortages in water supply, usually from precipitation but may also refer to shortages in ground or surface water. It is usually identified through the observation of multiple biophysical indicators.
children.name: Changes in the intensity of drought

children.description: A drought is an event of prolongued shortages in water supply, usually from precipitation but may also refer to shortages in ground or surface water. It is usually identified through the observation of multiple biophysical indicators.
children.name: Changes in the length / duration of drought
Changes in the frequency of years without any rainfall
Changes in the number of clouds
Changes in the colour of clouds
Changes in the frequency of fog or misty days
Changes in the frequency of cloudy days

children.description: The ´duration of fog´ is defined as the period of time within a day in which fog occurs.
children.name: Changes in the length / duration of fog

children.description: ´Dew´ are tiny droplets of water that form on cool surfaces during the night, when atmospheric vapour condenses.
children.name: Changes in the amount / intensity / strength of dew

children.description: ´Dew´ are tiny droplets of water that form on cool surfaces during the night, when atmospheric vapour condenses.
children.name: Changes in the number of days with dew

children.description: ´Frost´ is a deposit of small ice crystals that form on the ground or in other surfaces when temperature falls below freezing.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of frost days

children.description: ´Frost´ is a deposit of small ice crystals that form on the ground or in other surfaces when temperature falls below freezing.
children.name: Changes in the amount / intensity / strength of frost

children.description: ´Season´ is defined by a period of the year usually associated with a particular weather pattern and/or daylight hours, usually identified through the simultaneous observation of multiple biophysical indicators. A ´season´ could have a specific name (e.g., summer, winter) or be named according to specific weather patterns (e.g., rainy season, snow season).
children.name: Changes in the length /duration /disappearance of seasons

children.description: ´Season´ is defined by a period of the year usually associated with a particular weather pattern and/or daylight hours, usually identified through the simultaneous observation of multiple biophysical indicators. A ´season´ could have a specific name (e.g., summer, winter) or be named according to specific weather patterns (e.g., rainy season, snow season).
children.name: Changes in the timing (onset or end) of seasons

children.description: ´Season´ is defined by a period of the year usually associated with a particular weather pattern and/or daylight hours, usually identified through the simultaneous observation of multiple biophysical indicators. A ´season´ could have a specific name (e.g., summer, winter) or be named according to specific weather patterns (e.g., rainy season, snow season). Use this category when the local perception refers specifically to transitions between seasons (E.g., ´now summer comes suddenly, before it used to come gradually´)
children.name: Changes in the transition between seasons

children.description: Changes in the species assemblage within a certain vegetation type (e.g., forests now have different tree species). ´Species composition´ is the assemblage of species that is present in a given place, taking into account the identity and the number of individuals of each species.

children.description: ´Behaviour´ refers to the manifestation of specific biological or physiological phenomena. For example, ´species x used to wither the leaves in the afternoon, now it does it in the morning´, or ´the tree Y used to produce droplets of water in the leaves during the night, now not anymore´

children.description: ´Productivity´ means the rate of output per unit of input. Choose this option when the observation indicates that the system is producing less in general, without further specification. If the observation specifically mentions plant height, growth rate or size of plant parts, choose another option in this subsystem.

children.description: Diseases are defined as alterations of the phisiology or morphology of the plants by the action of biotic or abiotic agents. Biotic agents of diseases may be fungi, bacteria, viruses or nematodes. Abiotic agents of disease may  be climatic conditions, nutrient deficiency, etc.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of crop diseases (virus, fungi, bacteria, nematodes, etc)

children.description: Pests are defined as the massive appearance of living beings of the same species that cause serious damage to animal or crop populations.
children.name: Changes in the frequency of crop ´pests´ (insects, birds, larvae, etc)

children.description: Use this category specifically for species that occur in cropping systems and are considered invasive weeds
children.name: Changes in the frequency or occurrence of weed species stated as invasive
